abstracts.cdata!:
The Malawi Third Social Action Fund
            received a satisfactory outcome with moderate risk to
            development outcome. Both the Bank and the Borrower received
            satisfactory performance ratings. In addition to the
            restructurings done during the approval process of the
            additional financings, the Project had only one
            restructuring. It was done just before project closing to
            extend the closing date and was needed in order to apply
            some final reallocation and adjustment of amounts among
            components and categories. An Additional Financing (AF)
            project reworded the PDO to make it more concise and
            measurable without changing its substance. The revised PDO
            was: to improve the livelihoods of poor and vulnerable
            households and to strengthen the capacity of local
            authorities to manage local development. The changed PDO did
            not substantively change the objectives of the project, but
            clarified some aspects, including areas for which the
            project was to be held accountable. There were two AF
            projects. The first AF aimed to (i) develop, implement, and
            monitor a scaled-up public works-plus-savings and investment
            program to help alleviate the poverty, social, and economic
            impact of the crisis and (ii) provide financial assistance
            to protect core spending on education infrastructure
            investments through the reconstruction/retrofitting of
            education structures damaged in the Karonga and Chitipa
            earthquakes. The second AF was implemented as a
            stabilization package for the project which included
            additional support for the project, general budget support,
            and AF for an irrigation, rural livelihoods, and
            agricultural development project. There were several lessons
            learned from this project including the following: (1)
            safety net program parameters face trade-offs between cost,
            coverage, generosity, and durability of the infrastructure
            created and there is no right formula, (2) the focus on
            unskilled labor, largely road maintenance and afforestation,
            at less than market wages tended to increase womens
            participation, (3) finally, public works will definitely
            remain an important part of the social assistance tool kit
            in the country. The public works program (PWP) is scalable
            in times of crisis and can be directed to the right
            geographic locations and target groups.
